passage:
(1) Rivers and lakes are both essential bodies of water that sustain life on our planet, yet they differ significantly in their characteristics and functions. Rivers are flowing water bodies that move continuously in one direction, usually originating from mountains or hills and eventually emptying into seas, oceans, or larger rivers. In contrast, lakes are relatively still water bodies contained in depressions in the land, surrounded by land on all sides except where a river or stream enters or exits.

(2) The movement of water creates one of the most noticeable differences between these two water bodies. Rivers are characterized by their constant flow, which can range from gentle streams to powerful currents. This continuous movement affects everything from water temperature to the types of organisms that can survive in river environments. Lakes, however, are generally stationary bodies of water with minimal flow except near inlets and outlets. The still nature of lakes allows for temperature stratification, where different layers of water have distinct temperatures.

(3) The physical formation of rivers and lakes also differs considerably. Rivers typically form when precipitation or melting snow accumulates in sufficient quantity to create a flow of water that carves channels into the land. Over time, these channels deepen and widen through erosion. Lakes, on the other hand, can form through various geological processes including glacier movement, volcanic activity, tectonic plate shifts, or even human intervention through dam construction.

(4) The ecosystems supported by rivers and lakes vary due to their different physical conditions. River ecosystems must adapt to flowing water and changing conditions. Species living in rivers often have special adaptations to prevent being swept away by currents. Lake ecosystems tend to be more stable and can support a wider variety of plant life, particularly around their shores. Lakes often develop distinct zones of plant and animal life extending from the shoreline to the deepest areas.

(5) Finally, rivers and lakes serve different roles in human civilization and development. Throughout history, rivers have been crucial for transportation, agriculture, and as boundaries between territories. They continue to be important for navigation, hydroelectric power generation, and as sources of irrigation water. Lakes, while also providing water for human use, are often valued for their recreational opportunities, aesthetic beauty, and as habitats for fish that provide food sources. Both water bodies face threats from pollution and climate change, making their conservation increasingly important.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly uses the present perfect tense?

options.B: She has lived in Paris for three years.
options.C: We did not finished our homework yet.
options.D: They are visiting London last summer.

questions.question: Choose the correct comparative form.

options.A: This book is more interesting than that one.
options.B: She is taller that her brother.
options.C: My car is more faster than yours.
options.D: This exercise is difficulter than the previous one.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct pronoun usage.

options.A: Him and me went to the cinema yesterday.
options.B: The teacher gave the books to she and I.
options.C: They invited my friend and me to dinner.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the past continuous correctly?

options.A: I was cook dinner when the phone rang.
options.B: She was watching TV when I arrived.
options.C: We were ate lunch at 1 pm yesterday.
options.D: They was playing football all afternoon.

questions.question: Choose the correct modal verb for giving advice.

options.A: You must see a doctor if you feel better.
options.B: You might drink more water to stay hydrated.
options.C: You should take some medicine if you have a headache.
options.D: You will rest for a few hours.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct preposition.

options.B: She arrived at the station in time.
options.C: We'll meet on Monday at 3:00 pm.
options.D: The book is in the table.

questions.question: Which sentence has the correct word order?

options.A: Always she goes to bed early.
options.C: I don't know where is the restaurant.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct conditional form.

options.A: If it rains tomorrow, we will stays at home.
options.B: If I had more money, I would buy a new car.
options.C: If she would study harder, she will pass the exam.
options.D: If we will arrive early, we get good seats.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the present simple correctly?

options.C: I am usually having breakfast at 7 am.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct passive voice.

options.A: This book was wrote by a famous author.
options.B: English is speaking in many countries.
options.C: The house was built last year.

questions.question: Choose the correct future form to express a plan.

options.A: I will meeting my friends later.
options.B: She going to travel next month.
options.C: We are going to visit our grandparents this weekend.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct article usage.

options.A: I need an umbrella because it's raining.
options.B: She is the best student in an class.
options.C: He bought a orange and some apples.
options.D: We visited a Eiffel Tower last year.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a correct relative clause?

options.A: The woman who house is next to mine is a teacher.
options.B: I know the boy which plays the piano.
options.C: The book that I'm reading is very interesting.
options.D: The city where I visited last year was beautiful.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct verb agreement.

options.A: Neither of them are coming to the party.
options.B: Each of the students have a notebook.
options.C: The team are playing well this season.
options.D: Everyone needs to bring their own lunch.

questions.question: Select the correct form of the gerund or infinitive.

options.A: She enjoys to swim in the ocean.
options.B: I decided studying more for the exam.
options.D: We hope finding a solution soon.

options.A: to be in favor of something
options.D: to help someone achieve their goals

questions.question: According to the passage, what is the main difference between rivers and lakes?

options.B: Rivers flow in one direction while lakes are relatively still.
options.C: Lakes contain more diverse ecosystems than rivers.
options.D: Rivers are artificial while lakes are natural.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a way lakes can form?
According to paragraph 2, what happens in lakes that doesn't typically occur in rivers?
What adaptation is mentioned as necessary for species living in rivers?

options.A: Ability to survive in very deep water
options.C: Ability to prevent being swept away by currents

questions.question: Which statement best summarizes paragraph 5?

options.A: Rivers are more important to humans than lakes.
options.B: Both rivers and lakes are threatened by pollution.
options.C: Rivers and lakes serve different but important roles in human civilization.
options.D: Rivers and lakes are primarily valued for their beauty.

questions.question: What does the passage suggest about lake ecosystems compared to river ecosystems?

options.A: Lake ecosystems are generally more stable.
options.C: Lake ecosystems are more resistant to pollution.
options.D: River ecosystems have more plant life.

questions.question: According to the passage, rivers typically originate from:
The passage mentions all of the following as historical uses of rivers EXCEPT:
What does the passage identify as a modern use of rivers?
What is the main purpose of this passage?

options.A: To argue that rivers are more important than lakes
options.B: To explain the formation of water bodies
options.C: To compare and contrast the characteristics of rivers and lakes
options.D: To discuss the environmental threats to water bodies
